citation.title: Computational characterization of novel nanostructured materials: A case study of NiCl<sub>2</sub>
citation.abstract: A computational approach combining dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT) and classical molecular dynamics is employed to characterize the geometrical and thermomechanical properties of a recently proposed 2D transition metal dihalide NiCl<sub>2</sub>. The characterization is performed using a classical interatomic force field whose parameters are determined and verified through the comparison with the results of DFT calculations. The developed force field is used to study the mechanical response, thermal stability, melting and solidification of a NiCl<sub>2</sub> monolayer on the atomistic level of detail. The 2D NiCl<sub>2</sub> sheet is found to be thermally stable at temperatures below its melting point of ~695 K. At higher temperatures, several subsequent structural transformations of NiCl<sub>2</sub> are observed, namely a transition into a porous 2D sheet and a 1D nanowire. The MD simulations of NiCl<sub>2</sub> cooling show that the molten NiCl<sub>2</sub> system solidifies into an amorphous porous 2D structure at T ~450 K. The resulting structure has lower cohesive energy with respect to the initial 2D sheet. The computational methodology presented through the case study of NiCl<sub>2</sub> can also be utilized to study the properties of other novel 2D materials, including recently synthesized NiO<sub>2</sub>, NiS<sub>2</sub>, and NiSe<sub>2</sub>.

notes.text: The potential was designed to describe the geometrical and thermomechanical characteristics of the 2D NiCl<sub>2</sub> material. It was checked against the interatomic distances obtained from DFT calculations, Young's modulus upon biaxial stretching of the NiCl<sub>2</sub> sheet, and the analysis of the thermal stability of the system including simulations of the melting and solidification processes.

This file and equations were provided by Alexey Verkhovtsev on March 19, 2024.  The .pdf collects the equation and parameter values as described in the paper.  The .pot file are the parameters as used by the MBN Explorer software package.
